Admission Date: [**2135-2-26**]        Discharge Date: [**2135-2-26**]

Date of Birth:  [**2118-2-16**]        Sex:

Service:


CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Trauma STAT via [**Location (un) 86**] [**Location (un) **] for motor
vehicle crash transfer from referring hospital.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 17-year-old male who
was involved in a single vehicle motor vehicle crash on the
day of admission. The patient was a restrained driver who
lost control of his vehicle with the result that the vehicle
struck a tree. The patient required quite a lengthy
extrication and was without a definitive airway for an
undetermined period of time. The patient was transferred from
the referring facility to the [**Hospital1 **] [**First Name (Titles) 2142**]
[**Last Name (Titles) **] by [**Location (un) 86**] [**Location (un) **]. Upon arrival, the patient had [**Initials (NamePattern4) **]
[**Last Name (NamePattern4) 2611**] coma score of 3. The initial findings were
essentially [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 2611**] coma score of 3.

After initial stabilization, workup consisted of imaging of
the head, cervical spine and chest. The chest x-ray revealed
a diffuse whiteout of the left chest compatible with both
hemorrhage and contusion. A left tube thoracostomy had been
accomplished. The CT scan revealed diffuse loss of great
white matter, differentiation loss of the sulci secondary to
a combination of head injury and diffuse anoxic injury. There
was a right to left shift of approximately 1 cm at the level
of septum pellucidum and the suprasellar cisterns were nearly
completely effaced. The findings were most consistent with
acute anoxic injury superimposed on intracranial hemorrhage.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the trauma ICU
in consultation with the neurosurgery service. An
intracranial monitor was placed and high ICP pressures were
initially encountered. The family was informed by both the
neurosurgery service and trauma service of the critical
nature of the head injury that it would likely preclude
survival. The patient was aggressively resuscitated and all
attempts were made to maintain an acceptable cerebral
perfusion pressure. All these efforts were to no avail. The
patient subsequently began having excessive hemorrhage out of
his left tube thoracostomy. Because of the future nature of
the injury, no additional resuscitation efforts were
entertained. The patient subsequently expired.



                        [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 449**] [**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], M.D.
